awd_titl_txt: IOS EDGE: Expanding the toolkit for functional genetics in threespine stickleback to place genomics into its natural context
awd_abstract_narration:
'To learn about human biology, researchers use non-human species as stand-ins, or 'models'. Because no single species is a perfect model of human biology, science benefits from a broad portfolio of model organisms, each with its own relevance to human biology. This project will create new methods to study an emerging model, the threespine stickleback (Gasterosteus aculeatus). This small fish offers an important advantage over traditional lab models. Since the glaciers retreated in the northern hemisphere ~12,000 years ago, many beneficial genetic variants have survived in thousands of distinct natural populations. Unlike laboratory genetic screens, which reveal mutations in genes causing abnormal development or physiology, these natural variants reveal biological innovations: new ways of resisting parasites, for instance. A large community of researchers (>100 labs) now studies stickleback to understand behavior, development, and immunology. The research team has identified candidate genes affecting important traits like brain and bone development, but require tools to experimentally alter gene function for confirmation. This grant will support a team of five researchers developing new gene-editing methods for stickleback. Because stickleback are easily studied in the wild as well, this research team can take the unique step of linking laboratory genetics back to gene function in their natural environment. The researchers will train undergraduates, graduate students, and researchers from around the world, via new online communities and in-person courses. The project will also build infrastructure (a stock center) to perpetuate research-useful populations and provide research experiences for Native American students and communities, exposing them to scientific studies of local native animals.

Stickleback are a leading model in organismal biology for several reasons: 1. Marine populations independently colonized many diverse coastal watersheds, yielding exceptional phenotypic variation from a massively replicated natural experiment. 2. Ancestral alleles persist in modern oceanic populations, enabling genetic mapping of adaptive traits in known ecological contexts. 3. Stickleback are easy to breed and manipulate in large numbers in the lab and in nature. 4. Published genomes, transcriptomes, and microbiomes provide references for robust candidate gene identification and probe development. Consequently, hundreds of researchers study the genetics of stickleback adaptation. However, this research is largely confined to correlative approaches: QTL mapping, divergence mapping, and association studies. It remains rare for researchers to validate suspected candidate genes using experimental gene manipulation. To enable functional genomic studies of stickleback, this project will refine methods for gene editing. First, the research team will use transcriptomics and ChIP-Seq to improve genome annotation, to better locate candidate genes. Second, they will develop methods for more efficient gene editing with CRISPR-Cas9 delivered via embryo microinjection or cell culture transfection, or using viral-mediated gene transfer. Finally, the team will construct a stock center where natural and transgenic lines can be maintained and shipped to users, enabling studies on standardized genetic backgrounds spanning sticklebacks? natural diversity. The work will be disseminated via webinars, methods blogs, cross training of students, and a large lab course. This will provide research training to undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs, and colleagues around the world, as well as Native American communities in Alaska.

por.por_cntn:
One of the core goals of biology is to understand how genetic variation leads to variation in organismal traits - behavior, immunity, shape, physiology, etc..  Doing so requires the ability to experimentally modify genes, then test whether that modification leads to a change in a trait, thus confirming the gene's role in generating the trait. This experimental genetic approach has been used for a couple decades in a small number of model organisms (fruit flies, mice, nematodes), but has been inaccessible to a large number of researchers studying other organisms. For instance, the threespine stickleback (a small north temperate fish) is an emerging model organism being used for research in developmental biology, behavior, immunology, ecology, toxicology, and more, but experimental genetic methods are relatively new, inefficient, and not widely adopted. This species exhibits exceptional genetic and phenotypic diversity due to its evolutionary history of repeated movement of marine fish into different freshwater watersheds following deglaciation. Stickleback adapt to their particular lake or stream, generating vast between-lake, lake-vs-stream, and marine-vs-freshwater genetic and phenotypic differences. Biologists have been eager to use this trait diversity to map the genetic basis of a wide array of traits, then use experimental genetics to confirm those mapped genes' effects on the traits. The purpose of this project was to expand access and efficiency of gene editing methods in stickleback. This goal was achieved through five elements. First, the Principal Investigators (PIs) improved the assembly and annotation of the stickleback genome, and built a new browser for researchers to access this data. The browser includes layers of data on gene expression in multiple tissues, both sexes, and in specific cell types using single-cell RNAseq, as well as data on chromatin packing and epigenetic modifications. Having the genome browser makes it easier for researchers to identify candidate genes of interest and design guide RNA probes for gene editing.  The website has in the final year of the project received visits from nearly 1000 unique visitors from 27 countries. The second contribution was developing improved methods for CRISPR/cas9 gene editing of embryos that will increase the efficiency of gene modifications, and easier screening. Based on these advances, the PI's lab (Bolnick, University of Connecticut) has adopted the protocol first developed by co-PI Miller (UCalifornia Berkeley), and now has the equipment to offer embryonic microinjection as a service to the broader stickleback community. Third, co-PI Allison Bell (Univ Illinois) developed a viral-mediated gene transfer protocol allowing gene insertion into somatic tissue (e.g., brains). This method is being disseminated via a workshop presented by Usan Dan ?From genes to behavior: Functional genetic tools in diverse organisms? at the Animal Behavior Society meeting in Costa Rica in July 2022. The fourth contribution has been the creation and dissemination of protocols for cell culture maintenance (fibroblasts, head kidney immune cells, and gut epithelial cells) for experimental genetics within cell cultures. These protocols have been adopted by other labs in the US and Europe. All of the above protocols for gene editing and somatic gene delivery and cell culture have been deposited on protocols.io public repositories for wide dissemination. The final facilitation step has been the creation of a stickleback stock center, the first of its kind for this species. Both US and international researchers will be able to place orders for stickleback embryos, sperm, gut microbes, or parasites, either wildtype (from one of ten different source populations) or gene edited with custom-requested guide RNA probes. The stock center is half built (two rooms) with two more rooms pending completion in July 2022. The stock center is now harboring stickleback, and is staffed with a full time technician. The next three years of the stock center operations are supported by a new grant from the Moore Foundation, which was made possible by the initial investment from the NSF.  Collectively, the above activities have created informational resources (genome browser, protocols), new methods and optimized existing methods, and institutional resources (stock center) that will enable more rapid progress in stickleback experimental genetics.
